mooring 0.1.0
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Mooring Response to Unidirectional Flow
    • Default Values for Mooring Elements
    • Object-orientation Scheme

Compute how a mooring is knocked down by a current

knockdown.Rd

The current may be a depth-independent or depth-dependent, as specified by the v argument.

knockdown(m, u = 1, debug = 0L)

Arguments

m

an object of the "mooring" class, usually created with discretise().
u

either a non-negative number indicating depth-independent velocity, or a function that returns that velocity as a function of the vertical coordinate. For the second case, note that the vertical coordinate is defined as height (in m) above the sea surface, so that e.g. v=function(z) 0.5*exp(z/100) mould be used to specify a current that is 0.5m/s at the surface, dropping exponentially through the water column, reaching to 0.18m/s a hundred metres below the surface.
debug

an integer controlling debugging. The default value of 0 means to work silently. Use a positive value to cause the function to print some information about intermediate results.

Author

Dan Kelley

Examples

library(mooring)
m <- anchor(depth=100) + wire(length=80) + float("HMB 20")
md <- discretise(m)
mdk <- knockdown(md, u=1)
plot(mdk)
